Many states and some key parts of the health care industry delayed gearing up much of this past year.
They assumed either the Supreme Court would rule the law unconstitutional - which it didn't - or else Mitt Romney and a Republican Congress would be elected and make the law go away.
That didn't happen, either.
Now one of the law's big implementation deadlines is bearing down fast, says Weil.
When it comes to insurance exchanges, states have days to decide whether they want to run their own or let the federal government do it for them.
Insurance exchanges are where people will go to shop for insurance coverage.
They're also where people will get help paying for that coverage if they qualify for subsidies from the federal government.
So far, only 13 states and Washington, D.C., have said they'll set up their own exchange.
If states decide not to set up their own exchanges, the federal government will step in and do it instead.
But federal officials haven't spelled out exactly how that will work.
And opponents of the law, like Michael Cannon of the libertarian Cato Institute, say it's still not out of the legal woods yet.
He says the problem goes back to those subsidies that will help people afford coverage starting in 2014.
Without them, the law is not going to work.
Health insurance markets are going to collapse right after health insurance premiums go sky high.
That's because, he contends, the law only makes those subsidies available through exchanges set up by states, and not by those run by the federal government.
That's also the contention of a lawsuit filed by the state of Oklahoma.
Other experts, including Alan Weil, disagree.
The law is not beautifully crafted, but there are enough cross-references within the statute to make it clear that the subsidies are meant to be available to everyone based on their income.
I don't think who runs the administrative apparatus is relevant, and I actually think the statute is quite clear in that regard.
Meaning the subsidies should be available whether the insurance exchanges are run by states or by the federal government.
Cannon says the law also faces yet another hurdle.
It's vulnerable because it was handed a defeat by the Supreme Court when the Supreme Court said that the Medicaid expansion is optional for states.
That led several Republican governors to vow they would not add millions of new low-income adults to their Medicaid programs, even though the federal government will pay most of the bill.
But now public hospitals and others who serve those currently uninsured people are agitating to bring that federal money in.
So those governors may find themselves under increasing pressure at home.
Julie Rovner, NPR News, Washington.
From Karachi to Cairo and beyond, attacks and protests against the United States have highlighted the divide between majority Muslim nations and the West.
For critics of a video that mocks the Prophet Muhammad, the issue is insulting Islam.
For Americans, the issue is the constitutional protection of free speech.

A more significant debate may be happening within majority Muslim nations.
It doesn't involve the U.S.
at all.

NPR's Eleanor Beardsley reports from Tunisia.
Tunisian artist Nadia Jelassi heads down to her studio in the basement of her house, but it's hard for her to concentrate on her work these days.
Jelassi's problems started last June when her sculptures joined other works of art at a Tunis gallery.
Jelassi says everything went well until the last day of the exhibit, when a man taking photos asked that some of the artworks be taken down.
(Through translator) Of course we refused.
But before long, he came back with a group of bearded men.
They scrawled ""Death to blasphemous artists"" on the gallery walls, and later that night, broke into the building and destroyed many of the pieces.

Soon, groups of bearded, hard-line Muslims known as Salafists began protesting around the country against what they perceive as un-Islamic art.
Artists and secular Tunisians held counterprotests.
Some of the confrontations became violent.
Jelassi says the Salafists' behavior didn't surprise her.
What happened next did.
(Through translator) I was called to appear before a judge by our so-called moderate Muslim government and charged with disturbing public order.
Frankly, this is a first for artists in Tunisia.
I was fingerprinted, and mug shots were taken.
I have a police record now.
Jelassi says she was so shaken by the judge's actions that when she got home, she took her own mug shots and pasted them onto her Facebook page.
The pictures sparked a campaign of support for freedom of expression.
Since Tunisia's revolution 20 months ago, the kind of religious extremists who were once jailed under the dictatorship have been harassing Tunisian artists, journalists and intellectuals.
Secular Tunisians accuse the government of turning a blind eye to their aggressions.
Tunisia's Islamist-led government did seem stunned by the attack on the American embassy this month and quickly condemned it.

that sparked the attack.

Germany is facing a major political crisis over immigration.
It threatens to topple the government and potentially end the political career of Chancellor Angela Merkel.
A regional party in her ruling coalition is demanding tighter rules for migrants entering the country, and that party vows to act unilaterally if the chancellor refuses.
Merkel has two weeks to reach a deal.
NPR's Soraya Sarhaddi Nelson reports from Berlin that may just delay the inevitable.
This scene three years ago of asylum-seekers thronging Munich's main train station is what the conservative Bavarian party allied with Chancellor Angela Merkel says must never be repeated.
More than a million migrants crossed the Austrian border into Germany through Bavaria since 2015.

Although that flow has slowed to a trickle, the migrants' impact on German society is a matter of constant debate, including by President Donald Trump, who tweeted inaccurately about it earlier today.
The Bavarian party wants to tighten rules governing the entry into Germany of migrants who are first registered in another EU country and those rejected for asylum.
Germany's interior minister and a senior leader of the Bavarian CSU party is Horst Seehofer.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
This is scandalous.
(Speaking German).
He told reporters the situation is scandalous.
Seehofer asked, what's the point of an order barring someone's entry into Germany if that person learns there are no consequences?
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
(Speaking German).

The interior minister and his party, which is facing a major challenge from far-right populists in upcoming regional elections, say they will unilaterally prevent migrants from crossing Bavaria's international borders if Berlin doesn't act.
A last-minute reprieve gives Merkel until July 1 to convince fellow European leaders to come up with a comprehensive policy to seal Europe's borders to unbridled migration.
If she fails, the CSU vows to break its decades-old alliance with the chancellor's Christian Democrats, which would likely lead to new elections.
That would benefit Germany's far right, just like the immigration issue has in at least a dozen other European countries.

(Speaking German).

(Speaking German).
She said it's vital to know what will happen to any migrants barred from entering Germany so they don't end up back here.
Merkel has two weeks to negotiate a new arrangement.
Otherwise, many political analysts here predict either the chancellor or her interior minister will have to resign.
Soraya Sarhaddi Nelson, NPR News, Berlin.
